docs.abstract: This is not your typical gadget review. That’s because it is time to rethink when to upgrade your iPhone.
docs.snippet: This is not your typical gadget review. That’s because it is time to rethink when to upgrade your iPhone.
docs.lead_paragraph: Over more than a decade of writing about technology, reviewing a new iPhone has long been one of my simplest assignments.

headline.main: IPhone 11 and 11 Pro Review: Thinking Differently in the Golden Age of Smartphones

docs.abstract: We tested the new suite of privacy tools in Apple’s latest mobile software, from minimizing location sharing to silencing robocalls.
docs.snippet: We tested the new suite of privacy tools in Apple’s latest mobile software, from minimizing location sharing to silencing robocalls.
docs.lead_paragraph: To get the latest security protections against viruses, exploits and whatever other nasty stuff is out there, it’s wise to keep the software for our devices updated.

headline.main: How to Make the Most of Apple’s New Privacy Tools in iOS 13
headline.print_headline: Making the Most of Apple’s New Privacy Tools

docs.abstract: Countries have clashed in recent years over how — and where — to tax companies that operate across borders, particularly those that sell online.
docs.snippet: Countries have clashed in recent years over how — and where — to tax companies that operate across borders, particularly those that sell online.
docs.lead_paragraph: Digital tax dodgers, take heed: International leaders have advanced a plan to prevent large multinational companies like Apple, Facebook and Amazon from avoiding taxes by shifting profits between countries.

headline.main: Tech Giants Shift Profits to Avoid Taxes. There’s a Plan to Stop Them.
headline.print_headline: Global Plan Would Close Tax Havens to Tech Giants

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

docs.abstract: Plus, YouTube promises to stop collecting data from children, and Apple unveils new iPhones.
docs.snippet: Plus, YouTube promises to stop collecting data from children, and Apple unveils new iPhones.
docs.lead_paragraph: Just when you thought things couldn’t get crazier with Brexit, the China trade war and online privacy issues — well, they did. Here’s a quick rundown of the biggest stories in business and tech, and what to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles

headline.main: The Week in Business: Walmart Takes a Stand on Gun Control, and Brexit Goes Off the Rails
headline.print_headline: The Week in Business: Walmart Takes a Stand on Gun Control, and Brexit Goes Off the Rails

docs.abstract: After losing top professors, college students are less likely to create artificial intelligence start-ups and get less venture funding, the research says.
docs.snippet: After losing top professors, college students are less likely to create artificial intelligence start-ups and get less venture funding, the research says.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, big tech companies have used huge salaries, bonuses and stock packages to lure artificial intelligence experts out of academia. Now, a study released on Friday says that migration has hurt the post-college prospects of students.

headline.main: When the A.I. Professor Leaves, Students Suffer, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Students Suffer When Teachers of A.I. Leave

docs.abstract: Casio’s basic watches have barely changed in decades, a rare achievement as planned obsolescence is elevated to a corporate art form, our columnist says.
docs.snippet: Casio’s basic watches have barely changed in decades, a rare achievement as planned obsolescence is elevated to a corporate art form, our columnist says.
docs.lead_paragraph: IPhones haven’t been selling particularly well, Apple reported this summer, but its watches are becoming wildly popular. And no wonder.

headline.main: Apple’s Watch Is Smarter, but My Casio Keeps Getting the Job Done
headline.print_headline: It Reports the Time. It’s What I Want.

docs.abstract: Senators at a hearing pushed for assurances that the F.T.C. and Justice Department would provide vigorous oversight of the companies.
docs.snippet: Senators at a hearing pushed for assurances that the F.T.C. and Justice Department would provide vigorous oversight of the companies.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators pressed top antitrust regulators on Tuesday to aggressively investigate the power of the country’s biggest tech companies, with some lawmakers questioning whether the officials had the will or resources to take on Silicon Valley’s richest businesses.

headline.main: Lawmakers Urge Aggressive Action From Regulators on Big Tech
headline.print_headline: Lawmakers Push Regulators to Aggressively Scrutinize Big Tech

docs.abstract: Plus, plaintiffs reached a tentative settlement in a gigantic lawsuit over the opioid crisis
docs.snippet: Plus, plaintiffs reached a tentative settlement in a gigantic lawsuit over the opioid crisis
docs.lead_paragraph: It was a good week for soybean farmers and a bad one for “Froopy” e-cigarettes. What are those, you ask? Read on and learn.

headline.main: This Week in Business: E-Cigarettes Take a Hit, and Gig Workers Get Good News

docs.abstract: The top results of many common searches in the company’s App Store were packed with its own apps, as concerns grow that Apple may be tipping the scales in its own favor.
docs.snippet: The top results of many common searches in the company’s App Store were packed with its own apps, as concerns grow that Apple may be tipping the scales in its own favor.
docs.lead_paragraph: The top results of many common searches in the company’s App Store were packed with its own apps, as concerns grow that Apple may be tipping the scales in its own favor.

headline.main: How Apple’s Apps Topped Rivals in the App Store It Controls

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Keith Collins

docs.abstract: “The Banker,” one of the tech giant’s first forays into film, was a day away from its premiere at AFI Fest in Los Angeles.
docs.snippet: “The Banker,” one of the tech giant’s first forays into film, was a day away from its premiere at AFI Fest in Los Angeles.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple canceled the premiere of “The Banker,” starring Samuel L. Jackson, on Wednesday, yanking the movie from its prestigious closing-night Thursday slot at the American Film Institute’s annual festival in Los Angeles.

headline.main: Apple Pulls Samuel L. Jackson Movie From Festival, Citing ‘Concerns’
headline.print_headline: Apple Scuttles Premier of ‘The Banker,’ Citing ‘Concerns’

byline.original: By Nicole Sperling and Julia Jacobs
